items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

CSS Nesting Improves with CSSNestedDeclarations â€” CSSNestedDeclarations is a new, CSS Working Group approved interface to fix some quirks of CSS nesting, such as declarations that come after style rules confusingly shifting up. Itâ€™s in Chrome from v130, and testing is underway in Firefox and Safari. Bramus shares a quick behind-the-scenesÂ here but in short: "This means that CSS nesting got a whole lot better as of Chrome 130."

Bramus Van Damme (Google)

Uh-oh, .io?Â The Disappearance of an Internet Domain? â€” The British government recently announced it was transferring sovereignty of the Chagos Islands to Mauritius. But how can geopolitics alter digital infrastructure? The decision may result in the loss of one of the tech and gaming industryâ€™s much-loved (though problematic) top-level domains: .io.

Gareth Edwards

The First Newsletter Dedicated to ProductÂ Engineers â€” The fastest growing startups increasingly rely on product engineers. These are engineers with the skills to figure out what to build. Product for Engineers is dedicated to sharing the skills and strategies needed to succeed in thisÂ role.

PostHog sponsor

"Automattic is Doing Open Source Dirty" â€” DHH (of Ruby on Rails fame) chimes in on the ongoing WordPress saga, which seems to show no sign of abating soon. He states a concern â€œabout the integrity of open source licensesâ€, adding that such â€œintegrity is under direct assault by Automatticâ€™s grotesque claim for WP Engineâ€™sÂ revenuesâ€. Matt Mullenweg of WordPress replied on X.

David Heinemeier Hansson

  • ğŸ§° Chrome 129 is rolling out now, here's what devs need to know.

Searching for a New CSS Logo â€” Did you know that there's an active, ongoing search for a logo to help visualize all things CSS and â€œaid in the marketing and promotion of the new CSS eraâ€? Thereâ€™s a bunch of discussion and suggested designs being shared in the CSS-NextÂ repo.

Ryan Trimble

Firefox 131 'Supercharges' CSS Variables Debugging â€” Version 131 of Mozillaâ€™s browser was released last week adding notable improvements to debugging CSS variables along with other InspectorÂ improvements.

Nicolas Chevobbe

Debugging a Slack Integration with Sentryâ€™s Trace View â€” Read how our engineers used Sentry on Sentry to fix a Slack integration issue, improving the overall userÂ experience.

Sentry sponsor

â–¶Â Â State Queries â€” Una and Adam discuss a future web capability that builds on container queries: state queries. This upcoming feature will, for example, be able to detect if a container is overflowing, when an element is scroll snapped, and when an element is stuck from position: sticky.

Chrome for Developers

Plain Vanilla: A Tutorial Website for Plain Vanilla Web Development â€” The incentive behind this project is to teach building complex and dynamic apps without complex tools â€“ just HTML, CSS, and JS, using modern features like Web Components, hash-based routing, etc.

Joeri Sebrechts

â–¶Â Â Web Components: Little Bits â€” In this ~20 minute video from the recent State of the Browser conference, David shares how he is using Web Components to help develop complex design systems as well as custom open-sourceÂ tools. More videos from the event are available too.

David Darnes

Building a Robust Frontend with Progressive Enhancement â€” The UK government website is a rare and successful example of running a huge, behemoth of a site, with strong, robust systems and sound user experience considerations. Here, they touch upon how progressive enhancement plays a crucial role in making thingsÂ tick.

UK Government

Mux

PlaceholderJS: Ridiculously Simple and Lightweight Placeholders â€” Available for use via a CDN or as a React component, these are simple SVG-based placeholders that you can customize (size, color, background, etc.) using URL or componentÂ parameters.

Owen Bick

Securing Node.js Express APIs with Clerk and React â€” Secure Express API endpoints and integrate authentication without the complexity of building it fromÂ scratch.

ZEON STUDIO

qrframe: A Library to Generate 'Pretty' QRÂ Codes â€” An odd project as the QR codes generated arenâ€™t always guaranteed to scan reliably, but if you can generate one that does, they're very striking. Could be useful for branding/fun use cases. You can play around with a live demoÂ here.

Kyle Zheng

Animated Favicon Generator: Tool to Create an Animated Favicon from a GIF
AE Studio

items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹662 â€” October 2, 2024 | Read on the web

Catching Up on the WordPress & WP Engine Situation â€” Thereâ€™s been plenty of continued drama in the WordPress world between Automattic and WP Engine â€”Â and this post attempts to bring us up to speed. More has happened since including â–¶ï¸ Matt Mullenweg sitting down with Theo Browne for a chat about the situation, and some new terms have beenÂ shared.

Geoff Graham

The HTTP QUERY Method â€” A draft spec for a new QUERY HTTP method, a â€œsafe, idempotent request method that can carry request contentâ€. Itâ€™s said to be desirable â€œwhen the data conveyed in a request is too voluminous to be encoded into the requestâ€™sÂ URIâ€. It's not quite GET, but it's not quiteÂ POST..

Reschke, Malhotra, Snell, Bishop

Build a Native App Experience with PWAs â€” Join Maximiliano Firtman for a detailed video course exploring how to create installable, offline-capable web apps. You'll learn how to create impressive Progressive Web Apps, explore various UI techniques, dig into how best to test and debug, and how to deploy your efforts to endÂ users.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Web Components Are Okay â€” Spent any time on social this week? You may have spotted many in the frontend community talking about and questioning the overall merit and utility of Web Components. Nolan ties a few of these arguments together, concluding that folks are generally â€œtalking past each other because theyâ€™re building different things with differentÂ constraintsâ€.

Nolan Lawson

CSS Masonry & CSS Grid â€” As mentioned last week, steam is picking up on a formal CSS solution for masonry layouts, but with two competing proposals and lots of various opinions on both flying around, itâ€™s good to take a high-level overview of where things stand â€” thatâ€™s what thisÂ is.

Geoff Graham

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸ†• Rachel Andrew brings us up to speed on what was new to the web platform in September, including Chrome and Edge adding calc-size() support.

  • ğŸ§­ Safari Technology Preview 204 is now available with updates to Accessibility, CSS, Forms, JavaScript, Service Workers, and more.

  • ğŸ’° Evan You has raised a good chunk of change for a new "unified development toolchain for the JavaScript ecosystem".

  • âœ¨ Google has cash prizes up for grabs as part of a new Chrome 'Built-in AI' challenge.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Interview With BjÃ¶rn Ottosson, Creator of the Oklab Color Space â€” A chat with the Swedish engineer who created the Oklab color space, covering how he approached developing an effective model, with good hue uniformity, while also handling lightness and saturationÂ well.

Philip JÃ¤genstedt

Whatâ€™s the Difference Between HTMLâ€™s Dialog Element and Popovers? â€” Whilst pretty similar in both look and functionality Chris highlights the important distinctions, differing APIs, and overall useÂ cases.

Chris Coyier

How To Manage Dangerous Actions In User Interfaces â€” An exploration of different strategies we can use to prevent users from making mistakes (such as unintentionally sending an email, placing an order, hitting publish on something, etc).

Victor Ponamariov

Preethi Sam

â–¶Â Â Fundamentals of Frontend Architecture â€” A free video course that covers â€œeverything you need to know to build robust and scalable frontend applicationsâ€. It covers architectural drivers, documentation, decision making, prototyping, implementation, andÂ more.

Maxi Ferreira

SVG Coding Examples: Useful Recipes for Writing Vectors byÂ Hand â€” Explores the basics of hand-coding SVGs, how to leverage JavaScript along the way, plus practical examples to demystify the inner workings of common SVGÂ elements.

Myriam Frisano

WorkOS: Start Selling to Enterprises with Just a Few Lines ofÂ Code â€” A modern B2B SaaS identity platform with APIs for SSO, SCIM, RBAC. Trusted by topÂ startups.

Why I Prefer WebStorm Over Visual Studio Code for Web Development

Eleventy v3.0 Is Now Available â€” A popular Node.js-based static site generator. This release is written in ESM with full ESM support, is 20% smaller, has 11% fewer dependencies, and installsÂ faster. The Eleventy Image utility hit v5 too.

Zach Leatherman

tailwind-to-inline: A Tailwind CSS to Inline Styles Converter â€” The target use case is email template creation. Quickly craft the templates using Tailwind CSS, but then inline everything for the finalÂ version.

Vardan Hakobyan

OctoPalm.js: A Lightweight JavaScript Utility to Add Customizable Search Functionality to Your Apps â€” Includes features like animated results, customizable scrollbars for lengthy search lists, and real-time results as the userÂ types.

Eddie Gulay

TinyJS: A Lightweight Library to Easily Generate and Customize DOM Elements â€” Includes a jQuery-like syntax for element selection, iteration, and appending content and adding properties to elements. Nothing you couldnâ€™t do with vanilla JS, but a much simplerÂ API.
